lines.text: Enter LEONATO, HERO, and BEATRICE, with a Messenger

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: I learn in this letter that Don Peter of Arragon comes this night to Messina.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: He is very near by this: he was not three leagues off when I left him.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: How many gentlemen have you lost in this action

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: But few of any sort, and none of name.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: A victory is twice itself when the achiever brings home full numbers. I find here that Don Peter hath bestowed much honour on a young Florentine called Claudio.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Much deserved on his part and equally remembered by Don Pedro: he hath borne himself beyond the promise of his age, doing, in the figure of a lamb, the feats of a lion: he hath indeed better bettered expectation than you must expect of me to tell you how.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: He hath an uncle here in Messina will be very much glad of it.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: I have already delivered him letters, and there appears much joy in him even so much that joy could not show itself modest enough without a badge of bitterness.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Did he break out into tears

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: In great measure.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: A kind overflow of kindness: there are no faces truer than those that are so washed. How much better is it to weep at joy than to joy at weeping!

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I pray you, is Signior Mountanto returned from the wars or no

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: I know none of that name, lady: there was none such in the army of any sort.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: What is he that you ask for, niece

lines.speaker: hero
lines.text: My cousin means Signior Benedick of Padua.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: O, hes returned and as pleasant as ever he was.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: He set up his bills here in Messina and challenged Cupid at the flight and my uncles fool, reading the challenge, subscribed for Cupid, and challenged him at the birdbolt. I pray you, how many hath he killed and eaten in these wars But how many hath he killed for indeed I promised to eat all of his killing.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Faith, niece, you tax Signior Benedick too much but hell be meet with you, I doubt it not.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: He hath done good service, lady, in these wars.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: You had musty victual, and he hath holp to eat it: he is a very valiant trencherman he hath an excellent stomach.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: And a good soldier too, lady.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: And a good soldier to a lady: but what is he to a lord

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: A lord to a lord, a man to a man stuffed with all honourable virtues.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: It is so, indeed he is no less than a stuffed man: but for the stuffing,well, we are all mortal.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: You must not, sir, mistake my niece. There is a kind of merry war betwixt Signior Benedick and her: they never meet but theres a skirmish of wit between them.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Alas! he gets nothing by that. In our last conflict four of his five wits went halting off, and now is the whole man governed with one: so that if he have wit enough to keep himself warm, let him bear it for a difference between himself and his horse for it is all the wealth that he hath left, to be known a reasonable creature. Who is his companion now He hath every month a new sworn brother.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Ist possible

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Very easily possible: he wears his faith but as the fashion of his hat it ever changes with the next block.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: I see, lady, the gentleman is not in your books.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: No an he were, I would burn my study. But, I pray you, who is his companion Is there no young squarer now that will make a voyage with him to the devil

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: He is most in the company of the right noble Claudio.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: O Lord, he will hang upon him like a disease: he is sooner caught than the pestilence, and the taker runs presently mad. God help the noble Claudio! if he have caught the Benedick, it will cost him a thousand pound ere a be cured.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: I will hold friends with you, lady.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Do, good friend.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: You will never run mad, niece.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: No, not till a hot January.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Don Pedro is approached.
Enter DON PEDRO, DON JOHN, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and BALTHASAR

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Good Signior Leonato, you are come to meet your trouble: the fashion of the world is to avoid cost, and you encounter it.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Never came trouble to my house in the likeness of your grace: for trouble being gone, comfort should remain but when you depart from me, sorrow abides and happiness takes his leave.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: You embrace your charge too willingly. I think this is your daughter.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Her mother hath many times told me so.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Were you in doubt, sir, that you asked her

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Signior Benedick, no for then were you a child.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: You have it full, Benedick: we may guess by this what you are, being a man. Truly, the lady fathers herself. Be happy, lady for you are like an honourable father.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: If Signior Leonato be her father, she would not have his head on her shoulders for all Messina, as like him as she is.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: I wonder that you will still be talking, Signior Benedick: nobody marks you.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: What, my dear Lady Disdain! are you yet living

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Is it possible disdain should die while she hath such meet food to feed it as Signior Benedick Courtesy itself must convert to disdain, if you come in her presence.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Then is courtesy a turncoat. But it is certain I am loved of all ladies, only you excepted: and I would I could find in my heart that I had not a hard heart for, truly, I love none.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: A dear happiness to women: they would else have been troubled with a pernicious suitor. I thank God and my cold blood, I am of your humour for that: I had rather hear my dog bark at a crow than a man swear he loves me.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: God keep your ladyship still in that mind! so some gentleman or other shall scape a predestinate scratched face.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: Scratching could not make it worse, an twere such a face as yours were.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Well, you are a rare parrotteacher.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: A bird of my tongue is better than a beast of yours.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I would my horse had the speed of your tongue, and so good a continuer. But keep your way, i Gods name I have done.

lines.speaker: beatrice
lines.text: You always end with a jades trick: I know you of old.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: That is the sum of all, Leonato. Signior Claudio and Signior Benedick, my dear friend Leonato hath invited you all. I tell him we shall stay here at the least a month and he heartily prays some occasion may detain us longer. I dare swear he is no hypocrite, but prays from his heart.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: If you swear, my lord, you shall not be forsworn. Let me bid you welcome, my lord: being reconciled to the prince your brother, I owe you all duty.
To DON JOHN

lines.speaker: don john
lines.text: I thank you: I am not of many words, but I thank you.

lines.speaker: leonato
lines.text: Please it your grace lead on

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Your hand, Leonato we will go together.
Exeunt all except BENEDICK and CLAUDIO

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Benedick, didst thou note the daughter of Signior Leonato

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I noted her not but I looked on her.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Is she not a modest young lady

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Do you question me, as an honest man should do, for my simple true judgment or would you have me speak after my custom, as being a professed tyrant to their sex

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: No I pray thee speak in sober judgment.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Why, i faith, methinks shes too low for a high praise, too brown for a fair praise and too little for a great praise: only this commendation I can afford her, that were she other than she is, she were unhandsome and being no other but as she is, I do not like her.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Thou thinkest I am in sport: I pray thee tell me truly how thou likest her.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Would you buy her, that you inquire after her

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Can the world buy such a jewel

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Yea, and a case to put it into. But speak you this with a sad brow or do you play the flouting Jack, to tell us Cupid is a good harefinder and Vulcan a rare carpenter Come, in what key shall a man take you, to go in the song

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: In mine eye she is the sweetest lady that ever I looked on.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I can see yet without spectacles and I see no such matter: theres her cousin, an she were not possessed with a fury, exceeds her as much in beauty as the first of May doth the last of December. But I hope you have no intent to turn husband, have you

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: I would scarce trust myself, though I had sworn the contrary, if Hero would be my wife.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Ist come to this In faith, hath not the world one man but he will wear his cap with suspicion Shall I never see a bachelor of threescore again Go to, i faith an thou wilt needs thrust thy neck into a yoke, wear the print of it and sigh away Sundays. Look Don Pedro is returned to seek you.
Reenter DON PEDRO

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: What secret hath held you here, that you followed not to Leonatos

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I would your grace would constrain me to tell.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: I charge thee on thy allegiance.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: You hear, Count Claudio: I can be secret as a dumb man I would have you think so but, on my allegiance, mark you this, on my allegiance. He is in love. With who now that is your graces part. Mark how short his answer isWith Hero, Leonatos short daughter.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: If this were so, so were it uttered.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Like the old tale, my lord: it is not so, nor twas not so, but, indeed, God forbid it should be so.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: If my passion change not shortly, God forbid it should be otherwise.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Amen, if you love her for the lady is very well worthy.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: You speak this to fetch me in, my lord.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: By my troth, I speak my thought.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: And, in faith, my lord, I spoke mine.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: And, by my two faiths and troths, my lord, I spoke mine.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: That I love her, I feel.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: That she is worthy, I know.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: That I neither feel how she should be loved nor know how she should be worthy, is the opinion that fire cannot melt out of me: I will die in it at the stake.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Thou wast ever an obstinate heretic in the despite of beauty.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: And never could maintain his part but in the force of his will.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: That a woman conceived me, I thank her that she brought me up, I likewise give her most humble thanks: but that I will have a recheat winded in my forehead, or hang my bugle in an invisible baldrick, all women shall pardon me. Because I will not do them the wrong to mistrust any, I will do myself the right to trust none and the fine is, for the which I may go the finer, I will live a bachelor.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: I shall see thee, ere I die, look pale with love.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: With anger, with sickness, or with hunger, my lord, not with love: prove that ever I lose more blood with love than I will get again with drinking, pick out mine eyes with a balladmakers pen and hang me up at the door of a brothelhouse for the sign of blind Cupid.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Well, if ever thou dost fall from this faith, thou wilt prove a notable argument.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: If I do, hang me in a bottle like a cat and shoot at me and he that hits me, let him be clapped on the shoulder, and called Adam.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Well, as time shall try: In time the savage bull doth bear the yoke.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: The savage bull may but if ever the sensible Benedick bear it, pluck off the bulls horns and set them in my forehead: and let me be vilely painted, and in such great letters as they write Here is good horse to hire, let them signify under my sign Here you may see Benedick the married man.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: If this should ever happen, thou wouldst be hornmad.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Nay, if Cupid have not spent all his quiver in Venice, thou wilt quake for this shortly.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I look for an earthquake too, then.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Well, you temporize with the hours. In the meantime, good Signior Benedick, repair to Leonatos: commend me to him and tell him I will not fail him at supper for indeed he hath made great preparation.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: I have almost matter enough in me for such an embassage and so I commit you

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: To the tuition of God: From my house, if I had it,

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: The sixth of July: Your loving friend, Benedick.

lines.speaker: benedick
lines.text: Nay, mock not, mock not. The body of your discourse is sometime guarded with fragments, and the guards are but slightly basted on neither: ere you flout old ends any further, examine your conscience: and so I leave you.
Exit

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: My liege, your highness now may do me good.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: My love is thine to teach: teach it but how, And thou shalt see how apt it is to learn Any hard lesson that may do thee good.

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: Hath Leonato any son, my lord

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: No child but Hero shes his only heir. Dost thou affect her, Claudio

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: O, my lord, When you went onward on this ended action, I lookd upon her with a soldiers eye, That liked, but had a rougher task in hand Than to drive liking to the name of love: But now I am returnd and that warthoughts Have left their places vacant, in their rooms Come thronging soft and delicate desires, All prompting me how fair young Hero is, Saying, I liked her ere I went to wars.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: Thou wilt be like a lover presently And tire the hearer with a book of words. If thou dost love fair Hero, cherish it, And I will break with her and with her father, And thou shalt have her. Wast not to this end That thou beganst to twist so fine a story

lines.speaker: claudio
lines.text: How sweetly you do minister to love, That know loves grief by his complexion! But lest my liking might too sudden seem, I would have salved it with a longer treatise.

lines.speaker: don pedro
lines.text: What need the bridge much broader than the flood The fairest grant is the necessity. Look, what will serve is fit: tis once, thou lovest, And I will fit thee with the remedy. I know we shall have revelling tonight: I will assume thy part in some disguise And tell fair Hero I am Claudio, And in her bosom Ill unclasp my heart And take her hearing prisoner with the force And strong encounter of my amorous tale: Then after to her father will I break And the conclusion is, she shall be thine. In practise let us put it presently.
Exeunt
